intro: Betula pendula subsp. fontqueri, commonly known as the weeping birch, is a deciduous tree native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its graceful, drooping branches that create a cascading effect, giving it a distinctive appearance. The tree produces small, yellowish-green catkins in early spring, followed by small, triangular leaves that turn golden in autumn. Its bark is smooth and white when young, developing into a flaky, darker texture as the tree matures. This subspecies is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and parks.
